comments:
I get a NPE when dragging and dropping a file into a directory that is read only.

Log File contains:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2007-05-15 10:43:56.751
!MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Transfer Operation".
!STACK 0
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.rse.ui.messages.SystemMessageDialog.<init>(SystemMessageDialog.java:165)
	at org.eclipse.rse.ui.messages.SystemMessageDialog.displayErrorMessage(SystemMessageDialog.java:594)
	at org.eclipse.rse.ui.messages.SystemMessageDialog.displayMessage(SystemMessageDialog.java:643)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.files.ui.view.SystemViewRemoteFileAdapter.doDrop(SystemViewRemoteFileAdapter.java:1989)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.ui.view.SystemDNDTransferRunnable.transferRSEResources(SystemDNDTransferRunnable.java:251)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.ui.view.SystemDNDTransferRunnable.runInWorkspace(SystemDNDTransferRunnable.java:572)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

-----------Enter bugs above this line-----------

------------------------------------------------
Does it matter whether this is local or remote?  I tried this with local using my dev driver but didn't get any messages or log entries.

It happens on Local for me using todays driver.  Did you make the directory read only within RSE?  If you did that doesn't actually make the directory read only.  You need to make the directory read only in Windows.

Is this a local/windows only thing?  My windows is in a strange state right now such that I can't take what windows sees as a read-only folder (RSE doesn't see it as such) and make it read-write (from windows explorer).  When I do, windows continues to see the folder as read-only, even though I can create files within the folder.

This is happening for me on local windows only.  

The steps I have used to make a folder read/execute only:
Go to Windows Explorer.
Find the folder you want to make read/execute only.
Right click and select properties.
Click Security.
Check Deny Write.
Click okay.

This way you won't be able to create new files/folders inside the folder.   The read only attribute you get when right clicking on a folder and going to properties doesn't seem to do anything.

Ah, I think I see... when you make a file read-only via the Security panel, it doesn't get a read-only attribute. So when RSE scans the file, it thinks it is writable, but trying to write it fails with an access denied error.

RSE should treat this situation gracefully, of course, and display the access denied error to the user. It's a great test case. I'm changing the target milestone to past M7, though, since it is not a very common scenario and the NPE doesn't really hurt badly.

Is there another way to make a directory read only?  When you create a new folder on Windows and go to the properties of that folder it already has read-only attributed selected, but you can create files in it.
.. which simply proofs that Windows sucks, doesn't it :-)

I even checked on Vista and that read-only attribute is still there.  

You can find out about the read-only attribute here: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/326549

Main thing is:
"Unlike the Read-only attribute for a file, the Read-only attribute for a folder is typically ignored by Windows, Windows components and accessories, and other programs. For example, you can delete, rename, and change a folder with the Read-only attribute by using Windows Explorer."
